text: In the other direction, the boundary went east from Sarid to the border of Kisloth-tabor, and from there to Daberath and up to Japhia.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then it continued east to Gath-hepher, Eth-kazin, and Rimmon and turned toward Neah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The northern boundary of Zebulun passed Hannathon and ended at the valley of Iphtah-el.
speaker: Narrator

text: The towns in these areas included Kattath, Nahalal, Shimron, Idalah, and Bethlehem—twelve towns with their surrounding villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: The homeland allocated to the clans of the tribe of Zebulun included these towns and their surrounding villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fourth allotment of land went to the clans of the tribe of Issachar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its boundaries included the following towns: Jezreel, Kesulloth, Shunem,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hapharaim, Shion, Anaharath,
speaker: Narrator

text: Rabbith, Kishion, Ebez,
speaker: Narrator

text: Remeth, En-gannim, En-haddah, and Beth-pazzez.
speaker: Narrator

text: The boundary also touched Tabor, Shahazumah, and Beth-shemesh, ending at the Jordan River—sixteen towns with their surrounding villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: The homeland allocated to the clans of the tribe of Issachar included these towns and their surrounding villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fifth allotment of land went to the clans of the tribe of Asher.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its boundaries included these towns: Helkath, Hali, Beten, Acshaph,
speaker: Narrator

text: Allammelech, Amad, and Mishal. The boundary on the west touched Carmel and Shihor-libnath,
speaker: Narrator

text: then it turned east toward Beth-dagon, and ran as far as Zebulun in the valley of Iphtah-el, going north to Beth-emek and Neiel. It then continued north to Cabul,
speaker: Narrator

text: Abdon, Rehob, Hammon, Kanah, and as far as Greater Sidon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the boundary turned toward Ramah and the fortress of Tyre, where it turned toward Hosah and came to the Mediterranean Sea. The territory also included Mehebel, Aczib,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ummah, Aphek, and Rehob—twenty-two towns with their surrounding villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: The homeland allocated to the clans of the tribe of Asher included these towns and their surrounding villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sixth allotment of land went to the clans of the tribe of Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its boundary ran from Heleph, from the oak at Zaanannim, and extended across to Adami-nekeb, Jabneel, and as far as Lakkum, ending at the Jordan River.
speaker: Narrator

text: The western boundary ran past Aznoth-tabor, then to Hukkok, and touched the border of Zebulun in the south, the border of Asher on the west, and the Jordan River on the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fortified towns included in this territory were Ziddim, Zer, Hammath, Rakkath, Kinnereth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Adamah, Ramah, Hazor,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kedesh, Edrei, En-hazor,
speaker: Narrator

text: Yiron, Migdal-el, Horem, Beth-anath, and Beth-shemesh—nineteen towns with their surrounding villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: The homeland allocated to the clans of the tribe of Naphtali included these towns and their surrounding villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seventh allotment of land went to the clans of the tribe of Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land allocated as their homeland included the following towns: Zorah, Eshtaol, Ir-shemesh,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shaalabbin, Aijalon, Ithlah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elon, Timnah, Ekron,
speaker: Narrator

text: Eltekeh, Gibbethon, Baalath,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehud, Bene-berak, Gath-rimmon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Me-jarkon, Rakkon, and the territory across from Joppa.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the tribe of Dan had trouble taking possession of their land, so they attacked the town of Laish. They captured it, slaughtered its people, and settled there. They renamed the town Dan after their ancestor.
speaker: Narrator

text: The homeland allocated to the clans of the tribe of Dan included these towns and their surrounding villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: After all the land was divided among the tribes, the Israelites gave a piece of land to Joshua as his allocation.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord had said he could have any town he wanted. He chose Timnath-serah in the hill country of Ephraim. He rebuilt the town and lived there.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the territories that Eleazar the priest, Joshua son of Nun, and the tribal leaders allocated as grants of land to the tribes of Israel by casting sacred lots in the presence of the Lord at the entrance of the Tabernacle at Shiloh. So the division of the land was completed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Joshua,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now tell the Israelites to designate the cities of refuge, as I instructed Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who kills another person accidentally and unintentionally can run to one of these cities; they will be places of refuge from relatives seeking revenge for the person who was killed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Upon reaching one of these cities, the one who caused the death will appear before the elders at the city gate and present his case. They must allow him to enter the city and give him a place to live among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the relatives of the victim come to avenge the killing, the leaders must not release the slayer to them, for he killed the other person unintentionally and without previous hostility.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the slayer must stay in that city and be tried by the local assembly, which will render a judgment. And he must continue to live in that city until the death of the high priest who was in office at the time of the accident. After that, he is free to return to his own home in the town from which he fled.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The following cities were designated as cities of refuge: Kedesh of Galilee, in the hill country of Naphtali; Shechem, in the hill country of Ephraim; and Kiriath-arba (that is, Hebron), in the hill country of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the east side of the Jordan River, across from Jericho, the following cities were designated: Bezer, in the wilderness plain of the tribe of Reuben; Ramoth in Gilead, in the territory of the tribe of Gad; and Golan in Bashan, in the land of the tribe of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: These cities were set apart for all the Israelites as well as the foreigners living among them. Anyone who accidentally killed another person could take refuge in one of these cities. In this way, they could escape being killed in revenge prior to standing trial before the local assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the leaders of the tribe of Levi came to consult with Eleazar the priest, Joshua son of Nun, and the leaders of the other tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came to them at Shiloh in the land of Canaan and said, “The Lord commanded Moses to give us towns to live in and pasturelands for our livestock.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So by the command of the Lord the people of Israel gave the Levites the following towns and pasturelands out of their own grants of land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Aaron, who were members of the Kohathite clan within the tribe of Levi, were allotted thirteen towns that were originally assigned to the tribes of Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The other families of the Kohathite clan were allotted ten towns from the tribes of Ephraim, Dan, and the half-tribe of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The clan of Gershon was allotted thirteen towns from the tribes of Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and the half-tribe of Manasseh in Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The clan of Merari was allotted twelve towns from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites obeyed the Lord’s command to Moses and assigned these towns and pasturelands to the Levites by casting sacred lots.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites gave the following towns from the tribes of Judah and Simeon
speaker: Narrator

text: to the descendants of Aaron, who were members of the Kohathite clan within the tribe of Levi, since the sacred lot fell to them first:
speaker: Narrator

text: Kiriath-arba (that is, Hebron), in the hill country of Judah, along with its surrounding pasturelands. (Arba was an ancestor of Anak.)
speaker: Narrator

text: But the open fields beyond the town and the surrounding villages were given to Caleb son of Jephunneh as his possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following towns with their pasturelands were given to the descendants of Aaron the priest: Hebron (a city of refuge for those who accidentally killed someone), Libnah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jattir, Eshtemoa,
speaker: Narrator

text: Holon, Debir,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ain, Juttah, and Beth-shemesh—nine towns from these two tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Benjamin the priests were given the following towns with their pasturelands: Gibeon, Geba,
speaker: Narrator

text: Anathoth, and Almon—four towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: So in all, thirteen towns with their pasturelands were given to the priests, the descendants of Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the Kohathite clan from the tribe of Levi was allotted the following towns and pasturelands from the tribe of Ephraim:
speaker: Narrator

text: Shechem in the hill country of Ephraim (a city of refuge for those who accidentally killed someone), Gezer,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kibzaim, and Beth-horon—four towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following towns and pasturelands were allotted to the priests from the tribe of Dan: Eltekeh, Gibbethon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Aijalon, and Gath-rimmon—four towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: The half-tribe of Manasseh allotted the following towns with their pasturelands to the priests: Taanach and Gath-rimmon—two towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: So in all, ten towns with their pasturelands were given to the rest of the Kohathite clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Gershon, another clan within the tribe of Levi, received the following towns with their pasturelands from the half-tribe of Manasseh: Golan in Bashan (a city of refuge for those who accidentally killed someone) and Be-eshterah—two towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Issachar they received the following towns with their pasturelands: Kishion, Daberath,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jarmuth, and En-gannim—four towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Asher they received the following towns with their pasturelands: Mishal, Abdon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Helkath, and Rehob—four towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Naphtali they received the following towns with their pasturelands: Kedesh in Galilee (a city of refuge for those who accidentally killed someone), Hammoth-dor, and Kartan—three towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: So in all, thirteen towns with their pasturelands were allotted to the clan of Gershon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the Levites—the Merari clan—were given the following towns with their pasturelands from the tribe of Zebulun: Jokneam, Kartah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dimnah, and Nahalal—four towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Reuben they received the following towns with their pasturelands: Bezer, Jahaz,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kedemoth, and Mephaath—four towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Gad they received the following towns with their pasturelands: Ramoth in Gilead (a city of refuge for those who accidentally killed someone), Mahanaim,
speaker: Narrator

text: Heshbon, and Jazer—four towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: So in all, twelve towns were allotted to the clan of Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of towns and pasturelands within Israelite territory given to the Levites came to forty-eight.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every one of these towns had pasturelands surrounding it.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord gave to Israel all the land he had sworn to give their ancestors, and they took possession of it and settled there.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord gave them rest on every side, just as he had solemnly promised their ancestors. None of their enemies could stand against them, for the Lord helped them conquer all their enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not a single one of all the good promises the Lord had given to the family of Israel was left unfulfilled; everything he had spoken came true.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua called together the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them, “You have done as Moses, the servant of the Lord, commanded you, and you have obeyed every order I have given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: During all this time you have not deserted the other tribes. You have been careful to obey the commands of the Lord your God right up to the present day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now the Lord your God has given the other tribes rest, as he promised them. So go back home to the land that Moses, the servant of the Lord, gave you as your possession on the east side of the Jordan River.
speaker: Narrator

text: But be very careful to obey all the commands and the instructions that Moses gave to you. Love the Lord your God, walk in all his ways, obey his commands, hold firmly to him, and serve him with all your heart and all your soul.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua blessed them and sent them away, and they went home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses had given the land of Bashan, east of the Jordan River, to the half-tribe of Manasseh. (The other half of the tribe was given land west of the Jordan.) As Joshua sent them away and blessed them,
speaker: Narrator

text: he said to them, “Go back to your homes with the great wealth you have taken from your enemies—the vast herds of livestock, the silver, gold, bronze, and iron, and the large supply of clothing. Share the plunder with your relatives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the men of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh left the rest of Israel at Shiloh in the land of Canaan. They started the journey back to their own land of Gilead, the territory that belonged to them according to the Lord’s command through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: But while they were still in Canaan, and when they came to a place called Geliloth near the Jordan River, the men of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh stopped to build a large and imposing altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of Israel heard that the people of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh had built an altar at Geliloth at the edge of the land of Canaan, on the west side of the Jordan River.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the whole community of Israel gathered at Shiloh and prepared to go to war against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: First, however, they sent a delegation led by Phinehas son of Eleazar, the priest, to talk with the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this delegation were ten leaders of Israel, one from each of the ten tribes, and each the head of his family within the clans of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they arrived in the land of Gilead, they said to the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The whole community of the Lord demands to know why you are betraying the God of Israel. How could you turn away from the Lord and build an altar for yourselves in rebellion against him?
speaker: Narrator

text: Was our sin at Peor not enough? To this day we are not fully cleansed of it, even after the plague that struck the entire community of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And yet today you are turning away from following the Lord. If you rebel against the Lord today, he will be angry with all of us tomorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you need the altar because the land you possess is defiled, then join us in the Lord’s land, where the Tabernacle of the Lord is situated, and share our land with us. But do not rebel against the Lord or against us by building an altar other than the one true altar of the Lord our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Didn’t divine anger fall on the entire community of Israel when Achan, a member of the clan of Zerah, sinned by stealing the things set apart for the Lord? He was not the only one who died because of his sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh answered the heads of the clans of Israel:
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord, the Mighty One, is God! The Lord, the Mighty One, is God! He knows the truth, and may Israel know it, too! We have not built the altar in treacherous rebellion against the Lord. If we have done so, do not spare our lives this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: If we have built an altar for ourselves to turn away from the Lord or to offer burnt offerings or grain offerings or peace offerings, may the Lord himself punish us.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The truth is, we have built this altar because we fear that in the future your descendants will say to ours, ‘What right do you have to worship the Lord, the God of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord has placed the Jordan River as a barrier between our people and you people of Reuben and Gad. You have no claim to the Lord.’ So your descendants may prevent our descendants from worshiping the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So we decided to build the altar, not for burnt offerings or sacrifices,
speaker: Narrator

text: but as a memorial. It will remind our descendants and your descendants that we, too, have the right to worship the Lord at his sanctuary with our burnt offerings, sacrifices, and peace offerings. Then your descendants will not be able to say to ours, ‘You have no claim to the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “If they say this, our descendants can reply, ‘Look at this copy of the Lord’s altar that our ancestors made. It is not for burnt offerings or sacrifices; it is a reminder of the relationship both of us have with the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Far be it from us to rebel against the Lord or turn away from him by building our own altar for burnt offerings, grain offerings, or sacrifices. Only the altar of the Lord our God that stands in front of the Tabernacle may be used for that purpose.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Phinehas the priest and the leaders of the community—the heads of the clans of Israel—heard this from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh, they were satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Phinehas son of Eleazar, the priest, replied to them, “Today we know the Lord is among us because you have not committed this treachery against the Lord as we thought. Instead, you have rescued Israel from being destroyed by the hand of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Phinehas son of Eleazar, the priest, and the other leaders left the tribes of Reuben and Gad in Gilead and returned to the land of Canaan to tell the Israelites what had happened.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the Israelites were satisfied and praised God and spoke no more of war against Reuben and Gad.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Reuben and Gad named the altar “Witness,” for they said, “It is a witness between us and them that the Lord is our God, too.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The years passed, and the Lord had given the people of Israel rest from all their enemies. Joshua, who was now very old,
speaker: Narrator

text: called together all the elders, leaders, judges, and officers of Israel. He said to them, “I am now a very old man.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have seen everything the Lord your God has done for you during my lifetime. The Lord your God has fought for you against your enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have allotted to you as your homeland all the land of the nations yet unconquered, as well as the land of those we have already conquered—from the Jordan River to the Mediterranean Sea in the west.
speaker: Narrator

text: This land will be yours, for the Lord your God will himself drive out all the people living there now. You will take possession of their land, just as the Lord your God promised you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So be very careful to follow everything Moses wrote in the Book of Instruction. Do not deviate from it, turning either to the right or to the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make sure you do not associate with the other people still remaining in the land. Do not even mention the names of their gods, much less swear by them or serve them or worship them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rather, cling tightly to the Lord your God as you have done until now.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For the Lord has driven out great and powerful nations for you, and no one has yet been able to defeat you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each one of you will put to flight a thousand of the enemy, for the Lord your God fights for you, just as he has promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: So be very careful to love the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if you turn away from him and cling to the customs of the survivors of these nations remaining among you, and if you intermarry with them,
speaker: Narrator

text: then know for certain that the Lord your God will no longer drive them out of your land. Instead, they will be a snare and a trap to you, a whip for your backs and thorny brambles in your eyes, and you will vanish from this good land the Lord your God has given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Soon I will die, going the way of everything on earth. Deep in your hearts you know that every promise of the Lord your God has come true. Not a single one has failed!
speaker: Narrator

text: But as surely as the Lord your God has given you the good things he promised, he will also bring disaster on you if you disobey him. He will completely destroy you from this good land he has given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you break the covenant of the Lord your God by worshiping and serving other gods, his anger will burn against you, and you will quickly vanish from the good land he has given you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua summoned all the tribes of Israel to Shechem, including their elders, leaders, judges, and officers. So they came and presented themselves to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua said to the people, “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: Long ago your ancestors, including Terah, the father of Abraham and Nahor, lived beyond the Euphrates River, and they worshiped other gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I took your ancestor Abraham from the land beyond the Euphrates and led him into the land of Canaan. I gave him many descendants through his son Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text: To Isaac I gave Jacob and Esau. To Esau I gave the mountains of Seir, while Jacob and his children went down into Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then I sent Moses and Aaron, and I brought terrible plagues on Egypt; and afterward I brought you out as a free people.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when your ancestors arrived at the Red Sea, the Egyptians chased after you with chariots and charioteers.
speaker: Narrator

text: When your ancestors cried out to the Lord, I put darkness between you and the Egyptians. I brought the sea crashing down on the Egyptians, drowning them. With your very own eyes you saw what I did. Then you lived in the wilderness for many years.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Finally, I brought you into the land of the Amorites on the east side of the Jordan. They fought against you, but I destroyed them before you. I gave you victory over them, and you took possession of their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balak son of Zippor, king of Moab, started a war against Israel. He summoned Balaam son of Beor to curse you,
speaker: Narrator

text: but I would not listen to him. Instead, I made Balaam bless you, and so I rescued you from Balak.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you crossed the Jordan River and came to Jericho, the men of Jericho fought against you, as did the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Girgashites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites. But I gave you victory over them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I sent terror ahead of you to drive out the two kings of the Amorites. It was not your swords or bows that brought you victory.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave you land you had not worked on, and I gave you towns you did not build—the towns where you are now living. I gave you vineyards and olive groves for food, though you did not plant them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So fear the Lord and serve him wholeheartedly. Put away forever the idols your ancestors worshiped when they lived beyond the Euphrates River and in Egypt. Serve the Lord alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you refuse to serve the Lord, then choose today whom you will serve. Would you prefer the gods your ancestors served beyond the Euphrates? Or will it be the gods of the Amorites in whose land you now live? But as for me and my family, we will serve the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people replied, “We would never abandon the Lord and serve other gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord our God is the one who rescued us and our ancestors from slavery in the land of Egypt. He performed mighty miracles before our very eyes. As we traveled through the wilderness among our enemies, he preserved us.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was the Lord who drove out the Amorites and the other nations living here in the land. So we, too, will serve the Lord, for he alone is our God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua warned the people, “You are not able to serve the Lord, for he is a holy and jealous God. He will not forgive your rebellion and your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you abandon the Lord and serve other gods, he will turn against you and destroy you, even though he has been so good to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people answered Joshua, “No, we will serve the Lord!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You are a witness to your own decision,” Joshua said. “You have chosen to serve the Lord.”
“Yes,” they replied, “we are witnesses to what we have said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “All right then,” Joshua said, “destroy the idols among you, and turn your hearts to the Lord, the God of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people said to Joshua, “We will serve the Lord our God. We will obey him alone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua made a covenant with the people that day at Shechem, committing them to follow the decrees and regulations of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua recorded these things in the Book of God’s Instructions. As a reminder of their agreement, he took a huge stone and rolled it beneath the terebinth tree beside the Tabernacle of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua said to all the people, “This stone has heard everything the Lord said to us. It will be a witness to testify against you if you go back on your word to God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joshua sent all the people away to their own homelands.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Joshua son of Nun, the servant of the Lord, died at the age of 110.
speaker: Narrator

text: They buried him in the land he had been allocated, at Timnath-serah in the hill country of Ephraim, north of Mount Gaash.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel served the Lord throughout the lifetime of Joshua and of the elders who outlived him—those who had personally experienced all that the Lord had done for Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The bones of Joseph, which the Israelites had brought along with them when they left Egypt, were buried at Shechem, in the plot of land Jacob had bought from the sons of Hamor for 100 pieces of silver. This land was located in the territory allotted to the descendants of Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eleazar son of Aaron also died. He was buried in the hill country of Ephraim, in the town of Gibeah, which had been given to his son Phinehas.
speaker: Narrator
